Thus have I heard: Once, the Buddha was in the country of Shakya, traveling to Kapilavastu

I have heard the Buddha say that the human mind has three tendencies: the tendency towards desire, the tendency towards anger, and the tendency towards delusion.
Since I heard this, I have always kept it in mind and thought to myself:

'A mind without the tendency towards desire is upright by nature, a mind without the tendency towards anger is upright by nature, and a mind without the tendency towards delusion is upright by nature.'
I think to myself:
'Always holding this threefold mind without moving, why do I still not understand?' The Buddha said:
If one understands the mind of lust, anger, and delusion, why does one still live with a wife and children?
It is because of having a greedy mind.
The wise ones think to themselves:
'Although there is minor suffering now, in the long run there is great joy. Living with a wife and children brings only temporary joy, but in the long run there is great suffering.'
Do the wise ones know that worldly pleasures are few and suffering is much?

There are five kinds of happiness that people crave and delight in.
The eyes crave for beautiful colors.
They are immediately attached to the mind, day and night thinking of them with craving for beautiful colors;

The ears hear beautiful sounds, the nose smells beautiful fragrances, the tongue delights in delicious flavors, and the body experiences softness, they are immediately attached to the mind, with craving for beautiful colors.
In this way, these five things are craved by people in the world, and all worldly pleasures and attachments come from these five things.
How much worry should be known to come from them?

Worldly people, some make a living by farming, some make a living by crafts, some make a living by trade, some make a living by being officials, some make a living by raising livestock, and some make a living by painting.

These people endure cold when cold, endure heat when hot, endure suffering when suffering, endure hunger when hungry, and endure thirst when thirsty, all sitting with greedy minds, all enduring this cold, warmth, hunger, and thirst.
They complain to themselves, saying:

'I have been in business for several years, suffering to the point of death, and have not earned any money or property. I have lived in poverty and cold, and have sometimes become sick and emaciated.'
The Buddha told Manan:
This is one kind of suffering.
The second matter is the thought of greed and lust.

Among people, some work in the fields, some are craftsmen, some do business, some are government officials, some raise livestock, and some are painters. They endure the cold, heat, hunger, and thirst in their work, seeking to earn money and property.

Having obtained wealth, they are again filled with worry and fear, fearing that the county officials will lose their money and property, or that a fire will break out and burn their money and property, or that their ship will sink and lose their money and property, or that thieves will rob their money and property, or that their business will fail and lose their money and property, or that poor relatives will poison them with toxic drugs, or that their children will squander their money and property. These people always live with heavy worries, worrying day and night without a moment of relief.

There are also people who carry money and property, who may encounter county officials, water and fire, or goods sold without return, or who bury them in the ground and do not know their location, or who are falsely accused, or who have children who use their parents' money and property. These people think to themselves:
From a young age, I have endured cold, heat, hunger, and thirst, and endured hardships to obtain money and property, but now it is lost again.
Thinking like this, they may become ill or die, all due to money and wealth. This is all caused by the five desires and pleasures. This is the second suffering.

The third matter is that worldly people, due to money, argue with their fathers, brothers, and wives, or argue with their acquaintances and friends, or argue within their families. They slander each other behind their backs. This is all caused by greed and pleasure.

Worldly people, due to money and wealth, kings fight with kings, practitioners fight with practitioners, farmers fight with farmers, craftsmen fight with craftsmen, all due to money and wealth. They scold each other, beat each other with sticks, stab each other with knives, or injure or kill each other. This is all caused by greed. This is the third suffering.
The fourth matter is that worldly people join the army, accept official money, and are responsible for fighting, with no hope of life or death. They join the army out of greedy thoughts;

Since they cannot stop after receiving official money, they fight, either injuring or beheading each other, either injuring or cutting off each other's arms, or injuring or cutting off each other's legs, competing to take each other's lives. All of this is caused by greed, this is the fourth suffering.

The fifth matter is that worldly people, with greedy minds, travel at night, drilling holes in people's rooms, or robbing people on the road, attacking people's cities and fortresses. When caught by officials, they may have their heads cut off, hands cut off, feet cut off, be impaled, their flesh cut open, burned with fire, their foreheads beaten with a large mallet, their waists cut, all of this is caused by greedy thoughts, this is the fifth suffering.
Worldly people, because of money and wealth, deceive each other, deceiving each other with their mouths, bodies, and minds. At that time, they think it is acceptable and blameless;
they do not know that misfortune and poison will follow, and they will enter hell.
